docs.lead_paragraph: Justin Tuck’s commitment to getting children to read has become more than just the focus of his charity. It has also been the bedrock for Tuck and his wife as they get used to being parents.

headline.seo: For Giants’ Justin Tuck, Push for Reading Starts at Home
headline.main: For Giants’ Tuck, a Push for Reading Starts at Home
headline.print_headline: Tuck Shares His Love of Reading

docs.abstract: New York Giants defensive end Justin Tuck's commitment to getting children to read has become more than just the focus of his charity RUSH for Literacy, it is also the bedrock for Tuck and his wife as they get used to being parents.
docs.snippet: Justin Tuck’s commitment to getting children to read has become more than just the focus of his charity. It has also been the bedrock for Tuck and his wife as they get used to being parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: As access to devices has spread, children in poorer families are spending considerably more time using them for purposes other than for education.

headline.seo: New ‘Digital Divide’ Seen in Wasting Time Online
headline.main: Wasting Time Is New Divide in Digital Era
headline.print_headline: Wasting Time Is New Divide In Digital Era

docs.abstract: Studies show that as access to computing devices spreads, children in poorer families waste more time watching videos, playing games and connecting on social networking sites than children in higher income families; researchers say the growing time-wasting gap is more a reflection of the ability of parents to monitor and limit how children use technology rather than access to it; trend has prompted both public and private initiatives designed to improve digital literacy among parents and children alike.
docs.snippet: As access to devices has spread, children in poorer families are spending considerably more time using them for purposes other than for education.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.

headline.seo: Even in Kentucky, Coal Industry Is Under Siege
headline.main: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry
headline.print_headline: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry

docs.abstract: Planned switch from coal to natural gas announced by American Electric Power, the operator of the Big Sandy power plant in Kentucky, has caused an uproar in the state and is viewed by supporters of the coal industry as a capitulation to environmentalists; the coal industry is under siege across the United States, threatened by new federal regulations, environmentalists and natural gas companies intent on capturing much of the nation's energy market (Series: The Energy Rush).
docs.snippet: With the coal industry under siege across the country, an announcement that the operator of the Big Sandy power plant near Louisa, Ky., planned to switch to natural gas prompted an uproar.

byline.contributor: John M. Broder contributed reporting from Washington.

docs.lead_paragraph: LOUISA, Ky. -- For generations, coal has been king in this Appalachian town. It provided heat, light and jobs for the hundreds of people who worked in the nearby coal mines and the smoke-coughing Big Sandy power plant that burned their black bounty. But now, coal is in a corner. Across the United States, the industry is under siege, threatened by new regulations from Washington, environmentalists fortified by money from Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire mayor of New York City, and natural gas companies intent on capturing much of the nation's energy market.

headline.main: Even in Coal Country, the Fight for an Industry

docs.abstract: Planned switch from coal to natural gas announced by American Electric Power, the operator of the Big Sandy power plant in Kentucky, has caused an uproar in the state and is viewed by supporters of the coal industry as a capitulation to environmentalists; the coal industry is under siege across the United States, threatened by new federal regulations, environmentalists and natural gas companies intent on capturing much of the nation's energy market (Series: The Energy Rush).
